text: Howdy folks and welcome to this week's
news and community spotlights. We're
excited to announce the conclusion of
the Unreal Fellowship Games 2025 where
participants brought their ideas to life
by building fully playable games in just
3 weeks. This intensive hands-on boot
camp gave developers and artists a
chance to dive deep into Unreal Engine
while unleashing their creativity and
gaining practical experience as they
built their games from scratch. Learn
more at unrealeng engine.com/feed.
And be sure to check out their dev
diaries for insights, tips, and
behindthe-scenes look at the gamedev
processes of these amazing participants.
Get ready for a ride with Celio. They're
turbocharging human machine interfaces
in cars using Unreal Engine, slashing
development times from 5 years to just
three. With their tech already cruising
in over 30 million vehicles, they're all
about maximizing performance with Unreal
Insights. Cely is on a mission to create
not just smart dashboards, but an
exciting and memorable experience for
drivers. Buckle up and read more about
the future of driving on the feed.
[Music]
We're happy to announce that the sports
broadcast motion design sample project
is now available for free on Fab.
Developed in collaboration with Capacity
Studios, this fully designed and
animated project showcases a variety of
broadcast artist workflows using UEI's
motion design tool set. With features
like transition logic, rundown, and
material designer, it is an excellent
resource for designers and creators
looking to enhance their motion
graphics. Don't miss out and download it
on Fab today.
[Music]
Join your local chapter to learn, grow,
and be inspired. Here are some upcoming
events to check out.
Now, let's jump into this week's
stunning community spotlights.
Technical artist Nina Claus shines
bright with her latest project, Tropical
Beach. A stunning blend of technical
artistry and loving creativity. With
glittering sealass sands and a vibrant
atmosphere, this art piece captures the
intoxicating beauty felt when gazing out
into the ocean from the shore. This
project also includes breakdowns of
their process as well as some of the
tools they used to realize this
captivating piece. Be sure to swim over
to their art station to check out more
of their amazing work.
From magic missiles to bubble shields,
realtime VFX artist Max Angelen brings
these effects to life through rich
stylized systems that balance spectacle
with precision. Their work shines
through not just bold visuals, but in
the layers and details. secondary and
tertiary elements that add depth,
rhythm, and impact. Whether it's the
overlapping water dripping off of a
sphere or the final sparks and smoke of
an explosion, these effects feel
intentional and integrated. You can
check out more of their work on their
art station.
Abdul Hanov has come out swinging with
their project Tokyo Street. From the
large facades of the various buildings
down to the crates, cartons, and
buckets, this richly detailed scene
radiates with the warmth and
authenticity of the city while drawing
the viewer in with precise composition
and soft camera movements. Oh, and did
we mention that this was their first
environment project? They used this
piece as a means to learn the entire
environment pipeline from scratch, and
we think they absolutely nailed it. If
you're as impressed as we are, you can
find more of their work, including
breakdowns of this project, on their art
station.
That's all for this week. Thank you so
much for watching and we'll see you next
time.
[Music]
